Privacy For Free: Wireless Federated Learning Via
Uncoded Transmission With Adaptive Power Control

Dongzhu Liu and Osvaldo Simeone The authors are with King’s Communications, Learning, and Information Processing (KCLIP) lab at the Department of Engineering of Kings College London, UK (emails: dongzhu.liu@kcl.ac.uk, osvaldo.simeone@kcl.ac.uk). The authors have received funding from the European Research Council (ERC) under the European Unions Horizon 2020 Research and Innovation Programme (Grant Agreement No. 725731).
Abstract

Federated Learning (FL) refers to distributed protocols that avoid direct raw data exchange among the participating devices while training for a common learning task. This way, FL can potentially reduce the information on the local data sets that is leaked via communications. In order to provide formal privacy guarantees, however, it is generally necessary to put in place additional masking mechanisms. When FL is implemented in wireless systems via uncoded transmission, the channel noise can directly act as a privacy-inducing mechanism. This paper demonstrates that, as long as the privacy constraint level, measured via differential privacy (DP), is below a threshold that decreases with the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), uncoded transmission achieves privacy “for free”, i.e., without affecting the learning performance. More generally, this work studies adaptive power allocation (PA) for distributed gradient descent in wireless FL with the aim of minimizing the learning optimality gap under privacy and power constraints. Both orthogonal multiple access (OMA) and non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) transmission with “over-the-air-computing” are studied, and solutions are obtained in closed form for an offline optimization setting. Furthermore, heuristic online methods are proposed that leverage iterative one-step-ahead optimization. The importance of dynamic PA and the potential benefits of NOMA versus OMA are demonstrated through extensive simulations.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, differential privacy, adaptive power control, uncoded transmission.

I Introduction

In modern wireless systems, mobile devices generate and store data that can be utilized to train machine learning models [1, 2, 3]. While data at one device may be insufficient to obtain effective trained solutions, networked devices can benefit from data stored at other devices via communications. Federated learning (FL) refers to decentralized training protocols that avoid direct data sharing among devices, while exchanging information about the local models [4, 5]. This has the potential benefits of reducing the communication load and of leaking less information about the local data sets at the devices [6, 7, 8]. A well-established measure the privacy of local data sets with respect to disclosed aggregate statistics is differential privacy (DP) [9]. Typical DP mechanisms randomize the disclosed statistics by adding random noise [9]. This creates a trade-off between accuracy and privacy, as determined by the amount of added noise.

This paper investigates the idea of letting the channel noise serve as privacy mechanism. To this end, we focus on uncoded transmission of the gradients using either orthogonal or non-orthogonal protocols, and we analytically demonstrate that for these transmission schemes, privacy may be obtained “for free”. This is in the sense that enforcing a DP constraint causes no performance loss with respect to a non-private design as long as the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) is sufficiently low. More generally, we introduce a novel optimal closed-form adaptive transmit power control strategy that optimizes the learning performance while ensuring DP requirements.

I-A Wireless Federated Learning

A illustrated in Fig. 1, typical wireless FL protocols iterate between local adaptation and centralized combining. Adaptation involves local optimization steps based on a device’s data, while central aggregation amounts to averaging operations on the devices’ updates. To reduce the time to convergence, recent work has proposed to leverage computations over multiple access channels [10] as a primitive for the global combining step [11, 12, 13, 14, 15]. Accordingly, all devices simultaneously transmit their updates to edge server using uncoded transmission, which are aggregated “over-the-air” by exploiting the waveform-superposition property of a multi-access channel.

To further improve the bandwidth efficiency of this non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) scheme, devices can pre-process the analog updates via sparsification based dimensionality reduction [13]. And the learning performance of this approach can be further enhanced by gradient aware power control [14] and joint device selection and beamforming design [15].

As a more conventional solution, FL can be implemented using digital coded transmission. Under digital coded transmission and orthogonal multiple access (OMA), quantization of the local gradients has been proposed to trade off communication bandwidth and convergence rate [16], with each component of the gradient being represented even by a single bit [17]. More complex quantization schemes include hierarchical quantization via a low-dimensional codebook on a Grassmann manifold [18]. With NOMA, reference [19] proposes a strategy whereby each device quantizes the gradient based on its informativeness and on the channel condition. An alternative is to use one-bit quantization followed by BPSK/QPSK modulation at the devices with NOMA, and to estimate the aggregated gradient at the edger sever using majority voting [20].

I-B Differential Privacy for Federated Learning

According to its original motivation, FL may have desirable privacy properties since training is conducted in a distributed manner without sharing the raw data. Nevertheless, the model updates shared by the devices may reveal information about local data. For example, a malicious server could potentially infer the presence of an individual data sample from a learnt model by membership inference attack [21] or model inversion attack [7]. DP quantifies information leaked about individual data points by measuring the sensitivity of the disclosed statistics to changes in the input data set at a single data point. DP can be guaranteed by introducing a level of uncertainty into the released model that is sufficient to mask the contribution of any individual data point [9]. The most typical approach is to add random perturbations, e.g., Gaussian [22], Laplacian [23], or Binomial noise [24], to the released statistics.

DP mechanisms have been investigated for FL under the assumption that the edge server is “honest-but-curious” and that communication is noiseless and unconstrained. In [25], Gaussian noise is added to the local model updates, and the power of the Gaussian noise is adapted to ensure a target privacy level. Analysis indicates that there is a tradeoff between convergence rate and privacy protection levels. Furthermore, a higher privacy guarantee is achievable if the DP algorithm uses random mini-batches — the so-called “privacy amplification by subsampling” principle [26]. Another DP mechanism based on random quantization is explored in [27, 24].

While the work reviewed so far assumes ideal communication, several recent works have appeared that share the common theme of exploiting the channel noise for differentially private FL. In [28], each device adds Gaussian noise before transmission via NOMA with static power allocation. The superposition property of NOMA is shown not only to provide benefits in terms of efficient gradient aggregation, but also to offer better privacy guarantees. Instead of injecting noise before transmission, an energy efficient approach is to scale down the transmit power [29]. A digital counterpart of these ideas is proposed in [30] which uses quantized gradient descent with privacy-inducing binomial noise. The quantization bits and noise parameters are optimized to maximize the convergence rate under channel capacity and privacy constraints.

All the discussed works assume a simple static power allocation, not accounting for the fact that channel noise has a different impact on convergence and privacy level. As our analysis demonstrates, channel noise added in the first iterations tends to impact convergence less significantly than the noise added in later iterations, whereas the privacy level depends on a weighted sum of the inverse noise power across the iteration. These properties, captured by compact analytical expressions derived in this paper, are leveraged to define optimization problems that are solved in closed form, yielding significant performance gains over standard static power allocation.

I-C Contributions and Organization

In this paper, we study differentially private wireless distributed gradient descent via the direct, uncoded, transmission of gradients from devices to edge server. The channel noise is utilized as a privacy preserving mechanism and dynamic power control is separately optimized for OMA and NOMA protocols with the goal of minimizing the learning optimality gap under privacy and power constraints across a given number of communication blocks. The main findings and contributions of the paper can be summarized as follows.

∙∙\bullet Offline optimized power allocation for OMA and NOMA: Considering OMA and NOMA separately, we first analyze the convergence rate and privacy requirements for a given number of iterations under uncoded transmission. The resulting offline optimization problems are shown to be convex programs, and the optimal dynamic power allocation (PA) is obtained in closed form. The optimal PA is shown to be adaptive across the iterations, outperforming static PA assumed in prior works. The analytical results prove that privacy can be obtained “for free” as long as the privacy constraint level is below a threshold that decreases with the signal-to-noise (SNR). We also demonstrate that it is generally suboptimal to devote part of the transmitted power to actively add noise to the local updates. This is unlike the standard scenario with ideal communication, in which adding noise is essential to ensure DP constraints.

∙∙\bullet Online power allocation scheme: A heuristic online approach is then proposed that leverages iterative one-step-ahead optimization based on the offline closed-form solutions, predicted channel state information (CSI).

∙∙\bullet Experiments: We provide extensive numerical results that demonstrate the advantages of NOMA over conventional OMA protocols under DP constraints. We note here that these benefits is not a prior evident, since, with NOMA, devices transmit more frequently, and hence may leak more information if power is not properly allocated.

The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. Section II introduces the models and definitions. Section III presents the power allocation design for OMA. The design for NOMA is presented in Section IV. Section V provides numerical results, followed by conclusions in Section VI.

II Models and Definitions

As shown in Fig. 1, we consider a wireless federated edge learning system comprising a single-antenna edge server and K𝐾K edge devices connected through it via a shared noisy channel. Each device k𝑘k, equipped with a single antenna, has its own local dataset 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k}. This consists of labelled data samples {(𝐮i,vi)}∈𝒟ksubscript𝐮𝑖subscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝒟𝑘\{({\mathbf{u}}_{i},v_{i})\}\in\mathcal{D}_{k}, where 𝐮isubscript𝐮𝑖{\mathbf{u}}_{i} denotes the vector of covariates and visubscript𝑣𝑖v_{i} its associated label, which may be continuous or discrete. Local data sets are disjoint. A common regression or classification model, parameterized by vector 𝐰𝐰{\mathbf{w}}, is collaboratively trained by the edge devices through communications via edge server. In this section, we first introduce the learning protocol and the communication model, and then detail which the definition of differential privacy adopted in this work, along with main assumptions.

II-A Learning Protocol

This amounts to the regularized empirical average of the sample-wise loss functions on the global data set 𝒟=⋃k=1K𝒟k𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}=\bigcup_{k=1}^{K}\mathcal{D}_{k} obtained as the union of the local data sets. We note that the training loss (2) is an unbiased estimate of the generalization loss only if the devices observe independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.) samples from a common distribution. Nevertheless, this objective is also routinely considered for non-i.i.d. data sets in federated learning [31, 32, 33]. Other criteria that may be better suited to account for heterogeneous statistics across the devices may also be considered [34], but we leave this aspect for future work. The learning process aims to minimize the regularized global loss function as

𝐰∗=arg⁡min⁡F​(𝐰).superscript𝐰𝐹𝐰{\mathbf{w}}^{*}=\arg\min F({\mathbf{w}}). (3)

In order to address problem (3), we study a differentially private implementation of federated distributed gradient descent via gradient-averaging. As we will detail, privacy is defined here from the point of view of any device with respect to the edge server, which is assumed to be “honest-but-curious”. Accordingly, the edge server follows the protocol described below, but may attempt to infer information about data at the edge devices. We do not directly enforce privacy constraints on the other devices, which are implicitly trusted. More discussion on this point can be found in Section VI.

As illustrated in Fig. 1, at each t𝑡t-th communication round, with t=1,…,T𝑡1…𝑇t=1,\dots,T, the edge server broadcasts the current model iterate 𝐰(t)superscript𝐰𝑡{\mathbf{w}}^{(t)} to all edge devices via the downlink channel. We assume that downlink communication is ideal, so that each device receives the current model 𝐰(t)superscript𝐰𝑡{\mathbf{w}}^{(t)} without distortion. This assumption is practically well justified when the edge sever communicates through a base station with less stringent power constraint than the devices. By using the received current model 𝐰(t)superscript𝐰𝑡{\mathbf{w}}^{(t)} and the local dataset 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k}, each device computes the gradient of the local loss function in (II-A), that is

(Local gradient)​∇Fk​(𝐰(t))=1DkLocal gradient∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝐰𝑡1subscript𝐷𝑘\displaystyle{(\text{Local gradient})}\ \nabla F_{k}\big{(}{\mathbf{w}}^{(t)}\big{)}=\frac{1}{D_{k}} ∑(𝐮,v)∈𝒟k∇f​(𝐰(t);𝐮,v)subscript𝐮𝑣subscript𝒟𝑘∇𝑓superscript𝐰𝑡𝐮𝑣\displaystyle\sum_{({\mathbf{u}},v)\in\mathcal{D}_{k}}\nabla f\big{(}{\mathbf{w}}^{(t)};{\mathbf{u}},v\big{)}
+λ​∇R​(𝐰(t)).𝜆∇𝑅superscript𝐰𝑡\displaystyle\quad+\lambda\nabla R({\mathbf{w}}^{(t)}). (4)

The devices transmit information about the local gradient (II-A) over the wireless shared channel to the edge server. Based on the received signal, the edge server obtains an estimate ∇F^​(𝐰(t))^∇𝐹superscript𝐰𝑡\widehat{\nabla F}\left({\mathbf{w}}^{(t)}\right) of the global gradient

(Global gradient)∇F​(𝐰(t))=1D𝗍𝗈𝗍​∑k=1KDk​∇Fk​(𝐰(t)).Global gradient∇𝐹superscript𝐰𝑡1subscript𝐷𝗍𝗈𝗍superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐷𝑘∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝐰𝑡{(\text{Global gradient})}\quad{\nabla F}\left({\mathbf{w}}^{(t)}\right)=\frac{1}{D_{\sf tot}}\sum_{k=1}^{K}D_{k}\nabla F_{k}\left({\mathbf{w}}^{(t)}\right). (5)

The edge server then updates the current global model via gradient descent

(Model updating)𝐰(t+1)=𝐰(t)−η​∇F^​(𝐰(t)),Model updatingsuperscript𝐰𝑡1superscript𝐰𝑡𝜂^∇𝐹superscript𝐰𝑡{(\text{Model updating})}\quad{\mathbf{w}}^{(t+1)}={\mathbf{w}}^{(t)}-\eta\widehat{\nabla F}\left({\mathbf{w}}^{(t)}\right), (6)

where η𝜂\eta denotes the learning rate. The steps in (II-A), (5), and (6) are iterated until a convergence condition is met.

The transmission of the gradient (II-A) from each k𝑘k-th device may reveal information about the local data sets to the edge server. This motivates the use of DP as a rigorous mathematical framework to provide privacy guarantees that are agnostic to the computing resources and data processing requirements of the edge server. This will be detailed in Sec. II-C.

II-B Communication Model

All devices communicate via the uplink to the edge server on the shared wireless channel using uncoded transmission. The main focus of this paper is the study of uncoded non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA)111In this context, NOMA is used as a transmission strategy, and it does not imply the use of specific decoders, such as successive decoding. protocol, which enables over-the-air computing. For reference, we also study orthogonal multiple access (OMA) scheme under the same assumption of uncoded transmission. We note that it would be useful to include digital coded strategies for OMA as a benchmark. However, the design of digital communication protocols under DP constraints is a non-trivial problem that is currently subject to research [30].

We assume a block flat-fading channel, where the channel coefficients remain constant within a communication block, and they vary in a potentially correlated way over successive blocks. Each block contains d𝑑d channel uses, allowing the uncoded transmission of a gradient vector. Due to memory and processing complexity constraints, on-device machine learning models are typically of small size, so that the model parameters dimension d𝑑d can be assumed to be limited to a few tens of thousands of entries [35]. In this case, considering that typical coherence blocks may be of the same order of magnitude [36, 37], it is generally feasible to communicate the entire gradient vectors within one communication block. For larger model sizes, the gradient would need to be communicated across multiple coherence blocks – a setting that we leave for future investigations. We consider total I𝐼I blocks available for training.

As in most papers on over-the-air computing [11, 15, 13, 12, 28], we assume perfect channel state information (CSI) at all nodes, so that each device can compensate for the phase of its own channel, ensuring the effective channel hk[i]superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘delimited-[]𝑖h_{k}^{[i]} for each device k𝑘k and block i𝑖i is real and non-negative. This allows us to focus on a real channel model with non-negative channel gain, and it simplifies the design in power control parameters. We note that this assumption is also made in [14, 38], and that, as in these prior works, we do not make optimality claims in this regard. Details for OMA and NOMA are provided next.

II-B1 Orthogonal Multiple Access (OMA)

For orthogonal access, all devices time-share the channel uses via Time Division Multiple Access (TDMA). As illustrated in Fig. 2, devices are scheduled successively in orthogonal blocks, and we assume that the total number of blocks satisfies I=K​T𝐼𝐾𝑇I=KT, so that T𝑇T global gradient descent iterations (6) are implemented. In the i𝑖i-th block, with i=K​(t−1)+k𝑖𝐾𝑡1𝑘i=K(t-1)+k, device k𝑘k transmits gradient information corresponding to the t𝑡t-th iteration. The signal received at the edge server during the i𝑖i-th block is

where hk[i]≥0superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘delimited-[]𝑖0h_{k}^{[i]}\geq 0 is the channel gain for device k𝑘k in block i𝑖i, 𝐱k[i]∈ℝdsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑘delimited-[]𝑖superscriptℝ𝑑{\mathbf{x}}_{k}^{[i]}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} is an uncoded function of the local gradient ∇Fk​(𝐰(t))∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝐰𝑡\nabla{F}_{k}({\mathbf{w}}^{(t)}), and 𝐳k[i]superscriptsubscript𝐳𝑘delimited-[]𝑖{\mathbf{z}}_{k}^{[i]} is channel noise i.i.d. according to distribution 𝒩​(0,N0​𝐈)𝒩0subscript𝑁0𝐈\mathcal{N}(0,{N_{0}}{\mathbf{I}}). II-B2 Non-Orthogonal Multiple Access (NOMA)

For non-orthogonal access, we assume symbol-level synchronization among the devices that transmit simultaneously in each block. This can be achieved by using standard protocols such as the timing advance procedure in LTE and 5G NR [39]. In the i𝑖i-th block, all devices upload the local gradients corresponding to the t=i𝑡𝑖t=i-th iteration, and we have I=T𝐼𝑇I=T so that the number of blocks equals the number of iterations. The corresponding received signal is

where hk[i]superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘delimited-[]𝑖h_{k}^{[i]} and 𝐳[i]superscript𝐳delimited-[]𝑖{\mathbf{z}}^{[i]} are defined as above; and signal 𝐱k[i]∈ℝdsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑘delimited-[]𝑖superscriptℝ𝑑{\mathbf{x}}_{k}^{[i]}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} encodes information about the local gradient ∇Fk​(𝐰(t))∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝐰𝑡\nabla{F}_{k}({\mathbf{w}}^{(t)}) with t=i𝑡𝑖t=i. For NOMA, we will also write 𝐲(t)=𝐲[t]superscript𝐲𝑡superscript𝐲delimited-[]𝑡{\mathbf{y}}^{(t)}={\mathbf{y}}^{[t]}.

Note that for both forms of access, the transmit power constraint of a device is given as

(Power constraint)𝖤​[‖𝐱k[i]‖2]≤P.Power constraint𝖤delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑘delimited-[]𝑖2𝑃{(\text{Power constraint})}\quad\mathsf{E}[\|{\mathbf{x}}_{k}^{[i]}\|^{2}]\leq P. (9)

Accordingly, we define the maximum signal to noise ratio (SNR) as

𝖲𝖭𝖱𝗆𝖺𝗑=Pd​N0,subscript𝖲𝖭𝖱𝗆𝖺𝗑𝑃𝑑subscript𝑁0\mathsf{SNR}_{\sf max}=\frac{P}{dN_{0}}, (10)

II-C Differential Privacy

As a threat model, we assume a “honest-but-curious” edge server that may attempt to infer information about local data sets from the signals {𝐲(t)}t=1Tsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝐲𝑡𝑡1𝑇\{{\mathbf{y}}^{(t)}\}_{t=1}^{T} received across T𝑇T successive iterations. Note that, as discussed, T𝑇T iterations correspond to T𝑇T communication blocks for NOMA and T​K𝑇𝐾TK blocks for OMA. The standard definition DP imposes a point-wise upper bound on the divergence between the distributions P​(𝐲|𝒟)𝑃conditional𝐲𝒟P({\mathbf{y}}|\mathcal{D}) and P​(𝐲|𝒟′)𝑃conditional𝐲superscript𝒟′P({\mathbf{y}}|\mathcal{D}^{\prime}) of the received signals 𝐲={𝐲(t)}t=1T𝐲superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝐲𝑡𝑡1𝑇{\mathbf{y}}=\{{\mathbf{y}}^{(t)}\}_{t=1}^{T} conditioned on the use of either one of two “neighboring” global data sets 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} and 𝒟′superscript𝒟′\mathcal{D}^{\prime}. The two neighboring data sets 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} and 𝒟′superscript𝒟′\mathcal{D}^{\prime} differ only by one sample at one of the devices. Defining the cardinality of the set difference for two sets 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} and ℬℬ\mathcal{B} as ‖𝒜−ℬ‖1subscriptnorm𝒜ℬ1\|\mathcal{A}-\mathcal{B}\|_{1}, we have the following formal definition.

Definition 1 (Differential Privacy [9]).

The communication and learning protocol is (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-differentially private, where ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0, and δ∈[0,1)𝛿01\delta\in[0,1), if any two possible adjacent global datasets 𝒟′=⋃k=1K𝒟k′superscript𝒟′superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscriptsuperscript𝒟′𝑘\mathcal{D}^{\prime}=\bigcup_{k=1}^{K}\mathcal{D}^{\prime}_{k} and 𝒟′′=⋃k=1K𝒟k′′superscript𝒟′′superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘′′\mathcal{D}^{\prime\prime}=\bigcup_{k=1}^{K}\mathcal{D}_{k}^{\prime\prime}, with ‖𝒟j′−𝒟j′′‖1=1subscriptnormsubscriptsuperscript𝒟′𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝒟′′𝑗11\left\|\mathcal{D}^{\prime}_{j}-\mathcal{D}^{\prime\prime}_{j}\right\|_{1}=1 for some device j𝑗j and ‖𝒟k′−𝒟k′′‖1=0subscriptnormsubscriptsuperscript𝒟′𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝒟′′𝑘10\left\|\mathcal{D}^{\prime}_{k}-\mathcal{D}^{\prime\prime}_{k}\right\|_{1}=0 for all k≠j𝑘𝑗k\neq j, we have the inequality

P​(𝐲|𝒟′)≤exp⁡(ϵ)​P​(𝐲|𝒟′′)+δ.𝑃conditional𝐲superscript𝒟′italic-ϵ𝑃conditional𝐲superscript𝒟′′𝛿P({\mathbf{y}}|\mathcal{D}^{\prime})\leq\exp(\epsilon)P({\mathbf{y}}|\mathcal{D}^{\prime\prime})+\delta. (11)

The bound (11) can be interpreted in terms of the test variable.

(Differential privacy loss)ℒ𝒟′,𝒟′′​(𝐲)=ln⁡P​(𝐲|𝒟)P​(𝐲|𝒟′),Differential privacy losssubscriptℒsuperscript𝒟′superscript𝒟′′𝐲𝑃conditional𝐲𝒟𝑃conditional𝐲superscript𝒟′{(\text{Differential privacy loss})}\quad\mathcal{L}_{\mathcal{D}^{\prime},\mathcal{D}^{\prime\prime}}({\mathbf{y}})=\ln\frac{P({\mathbf{y}}|\mathcal{D})}{P({\mathbf{y}}|\mathcal{D}^{\prime})}, (12)

which is referred to as differential privacy loss. This corresponds to the log-likelihood ratio for the detection of neighboring data sets 𝒟′superscript𝒟′\mathcal{D}^{\prime} and 𝒟′′superscript𝒟′′\mathcal{D}^{\prime\prime}. The (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP condition (11) ensures that, for all possible adjacent global datasets 𝒟′superscript𝒟′\mathcal{D}^{\prime} and 𝒟′′superscript𝒟′′\mathcal{D}^{\prime\prime}, the absolute value of privacy loss variable (12) is bounded by ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta, i.e., Pr⁡(|ℒ𝒟′,𝒟′′​(𝐲)|≤ϵ)≥1−δPrsubscriptℒsuperscript𝒟′superscript𝒟′′𝐲italic-ϵ1𝛿\Pr(|\mathcal{L}_{\mathcal{D}^{\prime},\mathcal{D}^{\prime\prime}}({\mathbf{y}})|\leq\epsilon)\geq 1-\delta (see Lemma 3.17 in [9]). If ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon and δ𝛿\delta are suitably small, this makes it statistically impossible, even for an adversary that knows all data points in 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} except one, to identify the remaining individual sample.

II-D Assumptions On the Loss Functions

Finally, we list several standard assumptions we make on the loss functions and on its gradients.

Assumption 1 (Smoothness).

The global loss function F​(𝐰)𝐹𝐰F({\mathbf{w}}) is smooth with constant L>0𝐿0L>0, that is, it is continuously differentiable and the gradient ∇F​(𝐰)∇𝐹𝐰\nabla F({\mathbf{w}}) is Lipschitz continuous with constant L𝐿L, i.e.,

‖∇F​(𝐰)−∇F​(𝐰′)‖≤L​‖𝐰−𝐰′‖,for all ​𝐰,𝐰′∈ℝd.formulae-sequencenorm∇𝐹𝐰∇𝐹superscript𝐰′𝐿norm𝐰superscript𝐰′for all 𝐰superscript𝐰′superscriptℝ𝑑\left\|\nabla F({\mathbf{w}})-\nabla F({\mathbf{w}}^{\prime})\right\|\leq L\left\|{\mathbf{w}}-{\mathbf{w}}^{\prime}\right\|,\text{for all }{\mathbf{w}},{\mathbf{w}}^{\prime}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. (13)

Inequality (13) implies the following inequality

F​(𝐰′)≤F​(𝐰)+∇F​(𝐰)𝖳𝐹superscript𝐰′𝐹𝐰∇𝐹superscript𝐰𝖳\displaystyle F({\mathbf{w}}^{\prime})\leq F({\mathbf{w}})+\nabla F({\mathbf{w}})^{\sf T} (𝐰′−𝐰)+L2​‖𝐰−𝐰′‖2,superscript𝐰′𝐰𝐿2superscriptnorm𝐰superscript𝐰′2\displaystyle({\mathbf{w}}^{\prime}-{\mathbf{w}})+\frac{L}{2}\left\|{\mathbf{w}}-{\mathbf{w}}^{\prime}\right\|^{2},
for all ​𝐰,𝐰′∈ℝd.for all 𝐰superscript𝐰′superscriptℝ𝑑\displaystyle\text{for all }{\mathbf{w}},{\mathbf{w}}^{\prime}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. (14)
Assumption 2 (Polyak-Lojasiewicz Inequality).

The optimization problem (3) has a non-empty solution set. Furthermore, denoting as F∗superscript𝐹F^{*} the corresponding optimal function value, the global loss function F​(𝐰)𝐹𝐰F({\mathbf{w}}) satisfies the Polyak-Lojasiewicz (PL) condition, that is, the following inequality holds for some constant μ>0𝜇0\mu>0

12​‖∇F​(𝐰)‖2≥μ​[F​(𝐰)−F∗].12superscriptnorm∇𝐹𝐰2𝜇delimited-[]𝐹𝐰superscript𝐹\frac{1}{2}\left\|\nabla F({\mathbf{w}})\right\|^{2}\geq\mu\left[F({\mathbf{w}})-F^{*}\right]. (15)

The PL condition (15) is significantly more general than the standard assumption of strong convexity [40]. A strong convex with constant μ>0𝜇0\mu>0 implies the PL inequality with same parameter μ𝜇\mu [41]. Note also that for a convex loss function f​(⋅;𝐮,v)𝑓⋅𝐮𝑣f(\cdot;{\mathbf{u}},v), e.g., for least squares and logistic regression, the strong convexity of function F​(𝐰)𝐹𝐰F({\mathbf{w}}) follows from the addition of the regularizing term with λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0.

III Orthogonal Multiple Access

In this section, we consider the design and analysis of orthogonal multiple access with uncoded transmission and adaptive power control. To start, we assume that, at each iteration t𝑡t, device k𝑘k transmits a scaled and noisy version of the gradient 𝐱k[i]=𝐱k(t)superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑘delimited-[]𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑘𝑡{\mathbf{x}}_{k}^{[i]}={\mathbf{x}}_{k}^{(t)} in block i=K​(t−1)+k𝑖𝐾𝑡1𝑘i=K(t-1)+k as

𝐱k(t)=αk(t)​(Dk​∇Fk​(𝐰(t))+𝐧k(t)).superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑡subscript𝐷𝑘∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscript𝐰𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐧𝑘𝑡\displaystyle{\mathbf{x}}_{k}^{(t)}=\alpha_{k}^{(t)}\left(D_{k}\nabla F_{k}\left({\mathbf{w}}^{(t)}\right)+{\bf n}_{k}^{(t)}\right). (16)

In (16), the artificial noise term 𝐧k(t)∼𝒩​(0,(σk(t))2​𝐈)similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝐧𝑘𝑡𝒩0superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘𝑡2𝐈{\bf n}_{k}^{(t)}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,(\sigma_{k}^{(t)})^{2}{\mathbf{I}}) is added in accordance to the standard Gaussian mechanism in the DP literature; and αk(t)≥0superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑡0\alpha_{k}^{(t)}\geq 0 is a scaling factor. We note that, by (16), the effective noise in the received signal (7) is given by the summation of channel and artificial noise. The standard deviation of the effective noise is

mk(t)=(hk(t)​αk(t)​σk(t))2+N0.superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑘𝑡superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘𝑡2subscript𝑁0m_{k}^{(t)}=\sqrt{(h_{k}^{(t)}\alpha_{k}^{(t)}\sigma_{k}^{(t)})^{2}+N_{0}}. (17)

We are interested in optimizing over the sequences of parameters (αk(1),⋯,αk(T))superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘1⋯superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑇(\alpha_{k}^{(1)}\!,\!\cdots\!,\!\alpha_{k}^{(T)}) and (σk(1),⋯,σk(T))superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘1⋯superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘𝑇(\sigma_{k}^{(1)}\!,\!\cdots\!,\!\sigma_{k}^{(T)}) in order to maximize the learning performance under the (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP constraint. To this end, the remainder of this section first provides DP and convergence analysis, based on which the optimization problem is then formulated and solved. Throughout this section, we use the notation hk[i]=hk(t)superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘delimited-[]𝑖superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡h_{k}^{[i]}=h_{k}^{(t)}, 𝐲k[i]=𝐲k(t)superscriptsubscript𝐲𝑘delimited-[]𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐲𝑘𝑡{\mathbf{y}}_{k}^{[i]}={\mathbf{y}}_{k}^{(t)} and 𝐳k[i]=𝐳k(t)superscriptsubscript𝐳𝑘delimited-[]𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐳𝑘𝑡{\mathbf{z}}_{k}^{[i]}={\mathbf{z}}_{k}^{(t)} for i=K​(t−1)+k𝑖𝐾𝑡1𝑘i=K(t-1)+k, and we make the following common assumption (see, e.g., [42, 23, 43]).

Assumption 3 (Bounded Sample-Wise Gradient).

At any iteration t𝑡t, for any training sample (𝐮,v)𝐮𝑣({\mathbf{u}},v), the gradient is upper bounded by a given constant γ(t)superscript𝛾𝑡\gamma^{(t)}, i.e., for all possible (𝐮,v)𝐮𝑣({\mathbf{u}},v) (not limited to those in data sets {𝒟k}subscript𝒟𝑘\{\mathcal{D}_{k}\}) we have the inequality

III-A Differential Privacy Analysis

By standard results on DP, the privacy level (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta) depends on the sensitivity of the function being disclosed, excluding the effect of noise, to the input data set. More specifically, the sensitivity measures the amount by which a single individual data point can change the disclosed function in the worst case. For each device k𝑘k, the edge server is assumed to be informed about parameters {αk(t)}superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑡\{\alpha_{k}^{(t)}\}. We assume here that those parameters are fixed constants that do not reveal information about the local datasets. Hence, the only function of the data being disclosed is the received signal 𝐲k(t)superscriptsubscript𝐲𝑘𝑡{\mathbf{y}}_{k}^{(t)}, upon subtraction of the effective noise. The constraint (21) suggests that the effective noise variance can be adapted to the sequence of channel gains, as long as the impact on convergence is suitably accounted for.

Interestingly, the bound (2) suggests that noise added in the initial iterations is less damaging to the final optimality gap than the noise added in later iterations. This is because the contribution of the noise added at iteration t𝑡t is discounted by a factor (1−μ/L)T−tsuperscript1𝜇𝐿𝑇𝑡(1-\mu/L)^{T-t}. Under OMA, the optimization (25a)-(25c) over the additive noise deviations {σk(1),⋯,σk(T)}superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘1⋯superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘𝑇\{\sigma_{k}^{(1)},\cdots,\sigma_{k}^{(T)}\} and scaling factors {αk(1),⋯,αk(T)}superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘1⋯superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑇\{\alpha_{k}^{(1)},\cdots,\alpha_{k}^{(T)}\} for each devices k𝑘k can be carried out in parallel. s.t.formulae-sequencest\displaystyle{\rm s.t.}\quad ∑t=1T(2​γ(t))2(σk(t))2+N0/(hk(t)​αk(t))2≤ℛ𝖽𝗉​(ϵ,δ),superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscript2superscript𝛾𝑡2superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘𝑡2subscript𝑁0superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑡2subscriptℛ𝖽𝗉italic-ϵ𝛿\displaystyle\sum_{t=1}^{T}\frac{(\sqrt{2}\gamma^{(t)})^{2}}{(\sigma_{k}^{(t)})^{2}+{N_{0}}/(h_{k}^{(t)}\alpha_{k}^{(t)})^{2}}\leq\mathcal{R}_{\sf dp}(\epsilon,\delta), (26b)

(26c)

Without the DP constraint (26b), the optimal solution to problem (26) is to fully use the power budget P𝑃P for the transmission of the local gradient, i.e., to set αk(t)=P/(Dk​Gk(t))superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑡𝑃subscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑡\alpha_{k}^{(t)}=\sqrt{P}/(D_{k}G_{k}^{(t)}) and σk(t)=0superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘𝑡0\sigma_{k}^{(t)}=0 for all k𝑘k and t𝑡t. Due to the DP constraint, we now show that this may not be the optimal solution if the privacy condition is sufficiently strict.

Before detailing offline and online solutions, it is useful to observe that, in order for constraint (26b) to guarantee (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP, by leave t𝑡t, it is necessary that the parameters Gk(t)superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑡G_{k}^{(t)} be fixed at each iteration t𝑡t in a way that does not depend on the local data sets. We will return to this point when discussing online methods.

III-C1 Offline Optimization

We first assume that the parameters {hk(t),γ(t),Gk(t)}superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡superscript𝛾𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑡\{h_{k}^{(t)},\gamma^{(t)},G_{k}^{(t)}\} are known beforehand so that problem (26a)-(26c) can be tackled offline. As we show in Appendix -C, problem (26a)-(26c) can be converted into a convex program via a change of variables. The resulting optimal solution is described in the following theorem.

Theorem 1.

The optimal offline solution of problem (25a)-(25c) under OMA is given as follows:

  • •

    If condition

    ∑t=1TP​(2​γ(t)​hk(t))2N0​(Dk​Gk(t))2<ℛ𝖽𝗉​(ϵ,δ)superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇𝑃superscript2superscript𝛾𝑡superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡2subscript𝑁0superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑡2subscriptℛ𝖽𝗉italic-ϵ𝛿\sum_{t=1}^{T}\frac{P(\sqrt{2}\gamma^{(t)}h_{k}^{(t)})^{2}}{{N_{0}}(D_{k}G_{k}^{(t)})^{2}}<\mathcal{R}_{\sf dp}(\epsilon,\delta) (27)

    holds, there exists a unique optimal solution given as (αk(t))𝗈𝗉𝗍=P/(Dk​Gk(t))subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑡𝗈𝗉𝗍𝑃subscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑡(\alpha_{k}^{(t)})_{\sf opt}=\sqrt{P}/(D_{k}G_{k}^{(t)}) and (σk(t))𝗈𝗉𝗍=0subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘𝑡𝗈𝗉𝗍0(\sigma_{k}^{(t)})_{\sf opt}=0. In this case, the power budget P𝑃P is fully used for the transmission of the local gradient, and the channel noise is sufficient to guarantee privacy. The optimal solution is identical as that of without DP constraint, and privacy is hence obtained “for free”;

  • •

    Otherwise, there exist multiple optimal solutions, and the solution that minimizes the transmit power is

    (αk(t))𝗈𝗉𝗍subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑡𝗈𝗉𝗍\displaystyle(\alpha_{k}^{(t)})_{\sf opt} =min⁡{N0​(2​ζk)−14hk(t)​γ(t)​(1−μL)−t/4,PDk​Gk(t)}absentsubscript𝑁0superscript2subscript𝜁𝑘14superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡superscript𝛾𝑡superscript1𝜇𝐿𝑡4𝑃subscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑡\displaystyle=\min\bigg{\{}\frac{\sqrt{N_{0}}(2{\zeta_{k}})^{-\frac{1}{4}}}{h_{k}^{(t)}\sqrt{\gamma^{(t)}}}\left(1-\frac{\mu}{L}\right)^{-{t}/{4}}\!\!\!\!,\frac{\sqrt{P}}{D_{k}G_{k}^{(t)}}\bigg{\}} (28)
    (σk(t))𝗈𝗉𝗍subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘𝑡𝗈𝗉𝗍\displaystyle(\sigma_{k}^{(t)})_{\sf opt} =0,absent0\displaystyle=0, (29)

    where the value of parameter ζksubscript𝜁𝑘\zeta_{k} can be obtained by bisection to satisfy the constraint

    ∑t=1T(2​γ(t))2​minsuperscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscript2superscript𝛾𝑡2\displaystyle\sum_{t=1}^{T}{(\sqrt{2}\gamma^{(t)})^{2}}\min {(1−μ/L)−t/22​ζk​γ(t),P​(hk(t))2(N0​Dk​Gk(t))2}superscript1𝜇𝐿𝑡22subscript𝜁𝑘superscript𝛾𝑡𝑃superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡2superscriptsubscript𝑁0subscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑡2\displaystyle\bigg{\{}\frac{(1-\mu/L)^{-t/2}}{\sqrt{2\zeta_{k}}\gamma^{(t)}},\frac{P(h_{k}^{(t)})^{2}}{(\sqrt{N_{0}}D_{k}G_{k}^{(t)})^{2}}\bigg{\}}
    =ℛ𝖽𝗉​(ϵ,δ).absentsubscriptℛ𝖽𝗉italic-ϵ𝛿\displaystyle\qquad\qquad\quad\qquad=\mathcal{R}_{\sf dp}(\epsilon,\delta). (30)

    In this case, the transmitted power needs to be scaled down in order to leverage the channel noise to ensure (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP.

Proof: The proof is detailed in Appendix -C.

A first interesting observation from Theorem 1 is that it is optimal for the devices not to add noise to the transmitted signals (16). It is, in fact, sufficient to scale down their transmitted powers, via the choice of αk(t)superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑡\alpha_{k}^{(t)}, with smaller powers transmitted when more stringent DP constraints are imposed. Second, when condition (27) is satisfied, privacy is obtained “for free”, that is, without affecting the learning performance of the system, as the devices can use their full power. Third, condition (27) is less strict as Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} increases, showing that devices with larger datasets can attain privacy “for free” over a broader range of SNR levels. Finally, we note that it is generally suboptimal to use a time-invariant policy that sets the scaling factor αk(t)superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑡\alpha_{k}^{(t)} as a constant.

III-C2 Online Optimization

Theorem 1 assumes that the sequence of parameters {hk(t),γ(t),Gk(t)}superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡superscript𝛾𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑡\{h_{k}^{(t)},\gamma^{(t)},G_{k}^{(t)}\} is known a priori so as to enable offline optimization. Here we describe a heuristic online approach that leverages iterative one-step-ahead optimization based on predicted values for the future parameters {hk(t),γ(t),Gk(t)}superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡superscript𝛾𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑡\{h_{k}^{(t)},\gamma^{(t)},G_{k}^{(t)}\}.

To elaborate, assume that, at each iteration t𝑡t, we have predicted values {h^k(t′),γ^(t′),G^k(t′)}superscriptsubscript^ℎ𝑘superscript𝑡′superscript^𝛾superscript𝑡′superscriptsubscript^𝐺𝑘superscript𝑡′\{\widehat{h}_{k}^{(t^{\prime})},\widehat{\gamma}^{(t^{\prime})},\widehat{G}_{k}^{(t^{\prime})}\} for t′=t,t+1,⋯,Tsuperscript𝑡′𝑡𝑡1⋯𝑇t^{\prime}=t,t+1,\!\cdots\!,T and that the accumulated DP loss is given by ℒk(t−1)=∑t′=1t−1(2​hk(t′)​αk(t′)​γ(t′)/mk(t′))2superscriptsubscriptℒ𝑘𝑡1superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑡′1𝑡1superscript2superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘superscript𝑡′superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘superscript𝑡′superscript𝛾superscript𝑡′superscriptsubscript𝑚𝑘superscript𝑡′2\!\mathcal{L}_{k}^{(t-1)}\!\!\!=\!\!\sum_{t^{\prime}=1}^{t-1}(\!{\sqrt{2}h_{k}^{(t^{\prime})}\alpha_{k}^{(t^{\prime})}\gamma^{(t^{\prime})}}/{m_{k}^{(t^{\prime})}})^{2} from (21). As summarized in Algorithm 1, we propose to apply the solution in Theorem 1 to the interval (t,t+1,⋯,T)𝑡𝑡1⋯𝑇(t,t+1,\cdots,T) by replacing the true parameters {hk(t),γ(t),Gk(t)}superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡superscript𝛾𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑡\{h_{k}^{(t)},\gamma^{(t)},G_{k}^{(t)}\} with the estimates {h^k(t),γ^(t),G^k(t)}superscriptsubscript^ℎ𝑘𝑡superscript^𝛾𝑡superscriptsubscript^𝐺𝑘𝑡\{\widehat{h}_{k}^{(t)},\widehat{\gamma}^{(t)},\widehat{G}_{k}^{(t)}\} and the DP constraint with the residual ℛ𝖽𝗉​(ϵ,δ)−ℒk(t−1)subscriptℛ𝖽𝗉italic-ϵ𝛿superscriptsubscriptℒ𝑘𝑡1\mathcal{R}_{\sf dp}(\epsilon,\delta)-\mathcal{L}_{k}^{(t-1)}. We now discuss the problem of prediction of parameters {hk(t),γ(t),Gk(t)}superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡superscript𝛾𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑡\{{h}_{k}^{(t)},{\gamma}^{(t)},{G}_{k}^{(t)}\}.

IV Non-orthogonal Multiple Access

In this section, we consider the design and analysis of NOMA. For the t𝑡t-th iteration, local gradients are transmitted using the uncoded strategy (16). As in [11, 15, 13, 12, 28], we select the scaling factors αk(t)superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑡\alpha_{k}^{(t)} so as to ensure that, in the absence of noise, the edge server can recover a scaled version of the global gradient (5). Accordingly, we set

(Gradient Alignment)hk(t)​αk(t)=c(t),(Gradient Alignment)superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑡superscript𝑐𝑡\displaystyle\text{(Gradient Alignment)}\quad h_{k}^{(t)}\alpha_{k}^{(t)}=c^{(t)}, (36)

for some constant c(t)superscript𝑐𝑡c^{(t)}. We note that the effective noise in NOMA is equal to the summation of the channel noise and the contributions of artificial noise from all devices, and its standard deviation is given by

m(t)=(c(t))2​∑k=1K(σk(t))2+N0.superscript𝑚𝑡superscriptsuperscript𝑐𝑡2superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘𝑡2subscript𝑁0\displaystyle m^{(t)}=\sqrt{(c^{(t)})^{2}\sum_{k=1}^{K}(\sigma_{k}^{(t)})^{2}+N_{0}}. (37)

As per (36), in this section, we are optimizing over the parameters (c(1),⋯,c(T))superscript𝑐1⋯superscript𝑐𝑇(c^{(1)},\cdots,c^{(T)}) as well as over the added noise power (σk(1),⋯,σk(T))superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘1⋯superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘𝑇(\sigma_{k}^{(1)},\cdots,\sigma_{k}^{(T)}). Throughout this section, we denote hk[i]=hk(t)superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘delimited-[]𝑖superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡h_{k}^{[i]}=h_{k}^{(t)}, and 𝐳[i]=𝐳(t)superscript𝐳delimited-[]𝑖superscript𝐳𝑡{\mathbf{z}}^{[i]}={\mathbf{z}}^{(t)} for i=t𝑖𝑡i=t.

IV-A Differential Privacy Analysis

As discussed in Section III-A, the DP level depends on the sensitivity of the function being disclosed, which, in NOMA, for the same reasons discussed in Section III-A, is the received noiseless aggregated signal. The sensitivity to change in the data set of device k𝑘k is accordingly defined as

(Sensitivity in NOMA)Δk(t)=max𝒟k′,𝒟k′′∥c(t)×\displaystyle{(\text{Sensitivity in NOMA})}\ \ \Delta_{k}^{(t)}=\max_{\mathcal{D}^{\prime}_{k},\mathcal{D}^{\prime\prime}_{k}}\bigg{\|}{c^{(t)}}\times
(∑(𝐮,v)∈𝒟′∇f(𝐰(t);𝐮,v)−∑(𝐮,v)∈𝒟′′∇f(𝐰(t);𝐮,v))∥,\displaystyle\qquad\Big{(}\!\!\!\sum_{({\mathbf{u}},v)\in\mathcal{D}^{\prime}}\!\!\!\!\nabla f\big{(}{\mathbf{w}}^{(t)};{\mathbf{u}},v\big{)}\!-\!\!\!\!\!\sum_{({\mathbf{u}},v)\in\mathcal{D}^{\prime\prime}}\!\!\!\!\nabla f\big{(}{\mathbf{w}}^{(t)};{\mathbf{u}},v\big{)}\Big{)}\bigg{\|}, (38)

where ‖𝒟k′−𝒟k′′‖1=1subscriptnormsubscriptsuperscript𝒟′𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝒟′′𝑘11\left\|\mathcal{D}^{\prime}_{k}-\mathcal{D}^{\prime\prime}_{k}\right\|_{1}=1, ‖𝒟j′−𝒟j′′‖1=0subscriptnormsubscriptsuperscript𝒟′𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝒟′′𝑗10\left\|\mathcal{D}^{\prime}_{j}-\mathcal{D}^{\prime\prime}_{j}\right\|_{1}=0 for all j≠k𝑗𝑘j\neq k, and 𝒟′=⋃k=1K𝒟k′superscript𝒟′superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘′\mathcal{D}^{\prime}=\bigcup_{k=1}^{K}\mathcal{D}_{k}^{\prime}, 𝒟′′=⋃k=1K𝒟k′′superscript𝒟′′superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘′′\mathcal{D}^{\prime\prime}=\bigcup_{k=1}^{K}\mathcal{D}_{k}^{\prime\prime}. By Assumption 3, we can bound the sensitivity as

Δk(t)≤2​c(t)​γ(t).superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑘𝑡2superscript𝑐𝑡superscript𝛾𝑡\displaystyle\Delta_{k}^{(t)}\leq{2c^{(t)}}\gamma^{(t)}. (39)

Then, the DP guarantees for NOMA are given as follows.

Lemma 3 (Differential Privacy Guarantees for NOMA).

Federated gradient averaging via NOMA guarantees (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP if the following condition is satisfied

∑t=1T(2​c(t)​γ(t)m(t))2superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscript2superscript𝑐𝑡superscript𝛾𝑡superscript𝑚𝑡2\displaystyle\sum_{t=1}^{T}\left(\frac{\sqrt{2}c^{(t)}\gamma^{(t)}}{m^{(t)}}\right)^{2} ≤ℛ𝖽𝗉​(ϵ,δ),for all ​k.absentsubscriptℛ𝖽𝗉italic-ϵ𝛿for all 𝑘\displaystyle\leq\mathcal{R}_{\sf dp}(\epsilon,\delta),\ \text{for all }k. (40)

where m(t)superscript𝑚𝑡m^{(t)} is the standard deviation of the effective noise (37).

Proof: The proof follows in a manner similar to Lemma 1 by replacing the sensitivity and effective noise with those defined in NOMA.

Lemma 3 indicates that the effective noise contributing to the privacy of each device k𝑘k is given by the sum of channel noise and the privacy-inducing noise added by all devices. This is an important advantage of NOMA, which was also observed in [28].

IV-B Convergence Analysis

At the t𝑡t-th iteration, the edge server estimates the global gradient as

(41)
Lemma 4 (Optimality Gap Bound for NOMA).

Under Assumptions 1 and 2, for a learning rate η=1/L𝜂1𝐿\eta=1/L, after T𝑇T iterations the average optimality gap is upper bounded as

𝖤​[F​(𝐰(T+1))−F∗]≤(1−μL)T​[F​(𝐰(1))−F∗]𝖤delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝐰𝑇1superscript𝐹superscript1𝜇𝐿𝑇delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝐰1superscript𝐹\displaystyle\mathsf{E}\left[F\left({\mathbf{w}}^{(T+1)}\right)-F^{*}\right]\leq\left(1-\frac{\mu}{L}\right)^{T}\left[F\big{(}{\mathbf{w}}^{(1)}\big{)}-F^{*}\right]

where the standard deviation m(t)superscript𝑚𝑡m^{(t)} of the effective noise is defined in (37).

IV-C Optimization

In this section, we are interested in minimizing the optimality bound in Lemma 4 under the (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP constraint (40) and the power constraints (9) across T𝑇T iterations. The resulting optimization problem for NOMA (NOMA Opt.) is formulated as

min{σk(t),c(t)}k=1K​∑t=1T(1−μL)−t​∑k=1K(σk(t))2+N0/(c(t))2subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘𝑡superscript𝑐𝑡𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscript1𝜇𝐿𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘𝑡2subscript𝑁0superscriptsuperscript𝑐𝑡2\displaystyle\min_{{\{\sigma_{k}^{(t)},c^{(t)}\}}_{k=1}^{K}}\ \sum_{t=1}^{T}\left(1-\frac{\mu}{L}\right)^{-t}\sum_{k=1}^{K}(\sigma_{k}^{(t)})^{2}+{N_{0}}/(c^{(t)})^{2}\!\!\! (43a)
s.t.∑t=1T(2​γ(t))2∑k=1K(σk(t))2+N0/(c(t))2≤ℛ𝖽𝗉​(ϵ,δ)formulae-sequencestsuperscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscript2superscript𝛾𝑡2superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘𝑡2subscript𝑁0superscriptsuperscript𝑐𝑡2subscriptℛ𝖽𝗉italic-ϵ𝛿\displaystyle\qquad{\rm s.t.}\ \sum_{t=1}^{T}\frac{(\sqrt{2}\gamma^{(t)})^{2}}{\sum_{k=1}^{K}(\sigma_{k}^{(t)})^{2}+{N_{0}}/(c^{(t)})^{2}}\leq\mathcal{R}_{\sf dp}(\epsilon,\delta) (43b)
(c(t)hk(t))2​[(Dk​Gk(t))2+d​(σk(t))2]≤P,∀k,t.superscriptsuperscript𝑐𝑡superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡2delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑡2𝑑superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘𝑡2𝑃for-all𝑘𝑡\displaystyle\qquad\quad\left(\frac{c^{(t)}}{h_{k}^{(t)}}\right)^{2}\left[(D_{k}G_{k}^{(t)})^{2}+d(\sigma_{k}^{(t)})^{2}\right]\leq P,\ \forall k,t. (43c)

Without the DP constraint (43b), the optimal solution to problem (43) is determined by the devices with the smallest value of the ratio hk(t)/(Dk​Gk(t))superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡subscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑡{h_{k}^{(t)}}/{(D_{k}G_{k}^{(t)})} due to the need to satisfy the gradient alignment condition (36). In particular, the optimal solution prescribes that such devices use the full power budget P𝑃P to transmit the local gradient while the other devices transmit at the maximum power allowed under condition (36), i.e., c(t)=P​mink⁡hk(t)/(Dk​Gk(t))superscript𝑐𝑡𝑃subscript𝑘superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡subscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑡c^{(t)}=\sqrt{P}\min_{k}h_{k}^{(t)}/(D_{k}G_{k}^{(t)}) and σk(t)=0superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘𝑡0\sigma_{k}^{(t)}=0. We will see next that this is no longer the optimal solution under sufficiently strict DP constraints.

IV-C1 Offline Optimization

We first assume that the parameters {hk(t),γ(t),Gk(t)}superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡superscript𝛾𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑡\{h_{k}^{(t)},\gamma^{(t)},G_{k}^{(t)}\} are known beforehand so that problem (43a)-(43c) can be tackled offline. With a change of the variables, the problem can be shown to be convex. Unlike the previously studied problem for OMA, the optimization (43a)-(43c) cannot be solved in parallel across the devices.

Theorem 2.

The optimal offline solution of problem (43a)-(43c) under NOMA is given as follows:

  • •

    If condition

    2​PN0∑t=1T(γ(t))2mink(hk(t)Dk​Gk(t))2<ℛ𝖽𝗉(ϵ,δ)\displaystyle\frac{2P}{N_{0}}\sum_{t=1}^{T}(\gamma^{(t)})^{2}\min_{k}\left(\frac{h_{k}^{(t)}}{D_{k}G_{k}^{(t)}}\right)^{2}<\mathcal{R}_{\sf dp}(\epsilon,\delta) (44)

    holds, there exists a unique optimal solution given as (c(t))𝗈𝗉𝗍=P​mink⁡hk(t)/(Dk​Gk(t))subscriptsuperscript𝑐𝑡𝗈𝗉𝗍𝑃subscript𝑘superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡subscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑡(c^{(t)})_{\sf opt}=\sqrt{P}\min_{k}{h_{k}^{(t)}}/{(D_{k}G_{k}^{(t)})} and (σk(t))𝗈𝗉𝗍=0subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘𝑡𝗈𝗉𝗍0(\sigma_{k}^{(t)})_{\sf opt}=0. In this case, the devices with smallest value of the ratio hk(t)/(Dk​Gk(t))superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡subscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑡{h_{k}^{(t)}}/{(D_{k}G_{k}^{(t)})} transmit using the full power budget P𝑃P, while the other devices do not use full power. Therefore, under the gradient alignment condition (36), privacy is obtained “for free”;

  • •

    Otherwise, there exist multiple optimal solutions, and the solution that minimizes the transmit power at all devices is

    (c(t))𝗈𝗉𝗍subscriptsuperscript𝑐𝑡𝗈𝗉𝗍\displaystyle(c^{(t)})_{\sf opt} =min{N0​(2​ζ)−14γ(t)(1−μL)−t/4,\displaystyle=\min\bigg{\{}\frac{\sqrt{N_{0}}(2{\zeta})^{-\frac{1}{4}}}{\sqrt{\gamma^{(t)}}}\left(1-\frac{\mu}{L}\right)^{-{t}/{4}},
    Pminkhk(t)Dk​Gk(t)}\displaystyle\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\sqrt{P}\min_{k}\frac{h_{k}^{(t)}}{D_{k}G_{k}^{(t)}}\bigg{\}} (45)
    (σk(t))𝗈𝗉𝗍subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘𝑡𝗈𝗉𝗍\displaystyle(\sigma_{k}^{(t)})_{\sf opt} =0,absent0\displaystyle=0, (46)

    where the value of parameter ζ𝜁\zeta can be obtained by bisection to satisfy the constraint

    ∑t=1T(2γ(t))2min{(1−μ/L)−t/22​ζ​γ(t),\displaystyle\!\!\!\sum_{t=1}^{T}{(\sqrt{2}\gamma^{(t)})^{2}}\min\!\bigg{\{}\frac{(1-\mu/L)^{-t/2}}{\sqrt{2\zeta}\gamma^{(t)}}, PN0mink(hk(t)Dk​Gk(t))2}\displaystyle\frac{P}{N_{0}}\min_{k}\bigg{(}\frac{h_{k}^{(t)}}{D_{k}G_{k}^{(t)}}\bigg{)}^{2}\bigg{\}}
    =ℛ𝖽𝗉​(ϵ,δ).absentsubscriptℛ𝖽𝗉italic-ϵ𝛿\displaystyle=\mathcal{R}_{\sf dp}(\epsilon,\delta). (47)

    In this case, all the transmitted powers need to be scaled down in order to leverage the channel noise to ensure (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP.

Proof: The proof follows via the same steps of Theorem 1 by replacing the local optimization problem in OMA with the optimization problem of the device with smallest value of the ratio hk(t)/(Dk​Gk(t))superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡subscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑡{h_{k}^{(t)}}/{(D_{k}G_{k}^{(t)})}.

In a manner similar to OMA, Theorem 2 demonstrates that it is optimal for devices not to add further noise to the transmitted signals, i.e., to set 𝐧k(t)=0superscriptsubscript𝐧𝑘𝑡0{\mathbf{n}}_{k}^{(t)}=0 in (16). Furthermore, under condition (44), privacy is attainable “for free” since the optimal solution coincides with that obtained when excluding the DP constraint (43b). As for OMA, increasing the size Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} of the data sets makes condition (44) less restrictive.

IV-C2 Online Optimization

With the offline results in Theorem 2, we are ready to describe a heuristic online approach for NOMA which follows the same logic as in Section III-C. In particular, at each iteration t𝑡t, the edge server solves problem (43) over the interval [t,⋯,T]𝑡⋯𝑇[t,\cdots,T] of current and future time instants by using estimated parameters {hk(t),γ(t),Gk(t)}superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡superscript𝛾𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑡\{h_{k}^{(t)},\gamma^{(t)},G_{k}^{(t)}\}, and imposing the residual DP constraint for each device. We note that the optimization problem for NOMA is solved at edge server with the known values of {Dk}subscript𝐷𝑘\{D_{k}\}.

To detail the procedure summarized in Algorithm 2, channels are predicted as in (32). Parameter γ^^𝛾\widehat{\gamma} is set through the clipped per-sample gradient (III-C2). Finally, estimates {G^k(t)}superscriptsubscript^𝐺𝑘𝑡\{\widehat{G}_{k}^{(t)}\} are obtained by using the received signal of the last iteration as described in OMA, but averaged with the number of global data set, which is given as

G^k(t)={‖𝐲(t−1)‖/(c(t−1)​D𝗍𝗈𝗍),t>1,∀k,γ^,t=1,∀k,\displaystyle\widehat{G}_{k}^{(t)}=\left\{\begin{matrix}\|{\mathbf{y}}^{(t-1)}\|/(c^{(t-1)}D_{\sf tot}),&t>1,\forall k,\\ \widehat{\gamma},&t=1,\forall k,\end{matrix}\right. (48a)
G^k(t′)=G^k(t),∀t′>t,∀k.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript^𝐺𝑘superscript𝑡′superscriptsubscript^𝐺𝑘𝑡for-allsuperscript𝑡′𝑡for-all𝑘\displaystyle\widehat{G}_{k}^{(t^{\prime})}=\widehat{G}_{k}^{(t)},\forall\ t^{\prime}>t,\forall k. (48b)

One last issue to consider is that the optimized c(t)superscript𝑐𝑡c^{(t)} may violate the power constraint due to the use of estimated parameters. We hence modify the clipped gradient transmission as

(Clipped gradient transmission in NOMA)Clipped gradient transmission in NOMA\displaystyle{(\text{Clipped gradient transmission in NOMA})}
𝐱k(t)=min⁡{1,P​hk(t)c(t)​Dk​‖∇F¯k‖}​c(t)hk(t)​Dk​∇F¯k​(𝐰(t)).superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑘𝑡1𝑃superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡superscript𝑐𝑡subscript𝐷𝑘normsubscript¯∇𝐹𝑘superscript𝑐𝑡superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡subscript𝐷𝑘subscript¯∇𝐹𝑘superscript𝐰𝑡\displaystyle{\mathbf{x}}_{k}^{(t)}=\min\left\{1,\frac{\sqrt{P}h_{k}^{(t)}}{c^{(t)}D_{k}\|\overline{\nabla F}_{k}\|}\right\}\frac{c^{(t)}}{h_{k}^{(t)}}D_{k}\overline{\nabla F}_{k}\left({\mathbf{w}}^{(t)}\right). (49)

As for NOMA, we make no claims of optimality, and we test the performance of the proposed online scheme via numerical results in the next section.

V Numerical Results

In this section, we evaluate the performance of the proposed schemes in order to gain insights into the impact of the DP constraints and into the benefits of adaptive power allocation. Another benchmark is set by the scheme that doe not impose the DP constraint (26b) and (43b). We adopt the normalized optimality gap [F​(𝐰T+1)−F​(𝐰∗)]/F​(𝐰∗)delimited-[]𝐹superscript𝐰𝑇1𝐹superscript𝐰𝐹superscript𝐰[F({\mathbf{w}}^{T+1})-F({\mathbf{w}}^{*})]/F({\mathbf{w}}^{*}) as performance metric, and the offline results are averaged over 1000 channel realizations while online results are averaged over 100 channel realizations.

V-A Offline Optimization

We now focus on offline optimization by applying the optimal adaptive PA strategies in Theorems 1 and 2. For the channel model in (31), we set κ=10𝜅10\kappa=10, and the channel correlation parameter is set as ρ=1𝜌1\rho=1, since this parameter has no discernible effect on the performance of offline strategies. We use the simple upper bounds γ(t)=2​W​max(𝐮,v)∈𝒟⁡L​(𝐮,v)superscript𝛾𝑡2𝑊subscript𝐮𝑣𝒟𝐿𝐮𝑣\gamma^{(t)}=2W\max_{({\mathbf{u}},v)\in\mathcal{D}}L({\mathbf{u}},v) and Gk(t)=2​W​Lksuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑡2𝑊subscript𝐿𝑘G_{k}^{(t)}=2WL_{k}, where W≥‖𝐰‖𝑊norm𝐰W\geq\|{\mathbf{w}}\| is a bound on the norm ‖𝐰‖norm𝐰\|{\mathbf{w}}\| (which can be in practice ensured via convex projection and is set to W=3.2𝑊3.2W=3.2 in our results); and L​(𝐮,v)𝐿𝐮𝑣L({\mathbf{u}},v) and Lksubscript𝐿𝑘L_{k} are the Lipschitz smoothness constants of functions f​(𝐰;𝐮n,vn)𝑓𝐰subscript𝐮𝑛subscript𝑣𝑛f({\mathbf{w}};{\mathbf{u}}_{n},v_{n}) and Fk​(𝐰)subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰F_{k}({\mathbf{w}}), respectively.

In Fig. 3, we plot the normalized optimality gap as a function of the privacy level ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. In the considered range of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, NOMA with either adaptive or static power allocation (PA) is seen to achieve better performance than OMA. Furthermore, adaptive PA achieves a significant performance gain over static PA under stringent DP constraints, while the performance advantage of adaptive PA decreases as the DP constraint is relaxed, i.e., for larger values of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. The figure also shows the threshold values of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon beyond which the privacy “for free” conditions (27) and (44) are satisfied.

We now study the impact of the 𝖲𝖭𝖱𝗆𝖺𝗑subscript𝖲𝖭𝖱𝗆𝖺𝗑\mathsf{SNR}_{\sf max} (10) in Fig. 4. The normalized optimality gap of all schemes is seen to decrease with the SNR until the DP requirement becomes the performance bottleneck. While NOMA is confirmed to be generally advantageous over OMA, OMA with optimal PA can perform better than NOMA with static PA, which emphasizes the importance of PA optimization, particularly in the high-SNR regime. In a manner analogous to Fig. 3, the plot also marks the maximum SNR levels for which the privacy “for free” condition (27) and (44) are satisfied.

Fig. 5 plots the normalized optimality gap versus a measure of the heterogeneity of the data sets. To this end, one of the devices is allocated a lager value Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k}, while the remaining data points are evenly distributed to the other devices. The ratio maxk⁡Dk/D𝗍𝗈𝗍subscript𝑘subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝐷𝗍𝗈𝗍\max_{k}D_{k}/D_{\sf tot} varies from 0.10.10.1 (uniformly distributed) to 0.950.950.95 (highly skewed). Increasing data set heterogeneity generally affects negatively all schemes, even in the absence of privacy constraints. Nevertheless, the heterogeneity of Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} has a stronger impact for NOMA than for OMA due to gradient alignment condition (36). In particular, for NOMA, the power constraint becomes the performance bottleneck as the ratio max⁡Dk/D𝗍𝗈𝗍subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝐷𝗍𝗈𝗍\max D_{k}/D_{\sf tot} increases, and the performance of adaptive PA converges first to that without the DP constraint and then to that of static PA.

V-B Online Optimization

We now turn to the heuristic online optimization methods proposed in Algorithms 1 and 2. For the channel model in (31), we set κ=5𝜅5\kappa=5 and ρ=0𝜌0\rho=0. Note that channel prediction is possible due to the non-zero Rician factor. The maximum value of ‖𝐰‖norm𝐰\|{\mathbf{w}}\| is set as W=10𝑊10W=10, which is ensured by convex projection. Unless stated otherwise, we set the clipping threshold as γ^=20^𝛾20\widehat{\gamma}=20.

In Fig. 6, we study the impact of the communication budget in terms of number of communication blocks I𝐼I. With conventional static PA, there exists an optimal communication budget under privacy constraints. This is because more communication blocks may cause an increase in privacy loss (see also [25]). In contrast, increasing the communication budget always benefits adaptive PA, which is able to properly allocate power across the communication blocks. Furthermore, without DP constraint, the performance of OMA converges to that of NOMA when the communication budget I𝐼I is large; while, under privacy constraints, NOMA retains performance advantages even with a large I𝐼I.

Fig. 7 plots the normalized optimality gap versus the number of users. It shows that increasing the number of users has a negative effect on OMA, but it causes no harm to NOMA. This emphasizes the spectral efficiency of NOMA in wireless edge learning. Furthermore, under OMA, a larger number of users implies fewer iterations, and thus less information leakage of each user, decreasing the performances gain of adaptive PA. Specifically, when K=30𝐾30K=30, a simple iteration T=1𝑇1T=1 is carried out by OMA, and adaptive PA is equivalent to static PA.

We now study the impact of the clipping threshold γ^^𝛾\widehat{\gamma} for the gradient in Fig. 8. To show the impact of clipping, we also plot the performance with clipped local updates without the DP constraint for both OMA and NOMA. Without DP constraint, the larger clipping threshold incurs a smaller distortion of the gradients, which benefits the learning performance. However, under the DP constraint, increasing the clipping threshold beyond a given value degrades the performance, since ensuring privacy requires a more pronounced scaling down of the transmitted signals. This indicates the importance of selecting a threshold γ^^𝛾\widehat{\gamma} that strikes a balance between learning performance and privacy.

V-C MNIST Data Set

We now consider the problem of classification on the MNIST data set via multinomial logistic regression with quadratic regularization. Accordingly, the global loss function is given as the regularized cross-entropy loss

F​(𝐰)=1D𝗍𝗈𝗍​∑(𝐮,v)∈𝒟∑c=1C𝟏​{v=c}𝐹𝐰1subscript𝐷𝗍𝗈𝗍subscript𝐮𝑣𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑐1𝐶1𝑣𝑐\displaystyle F({\mathbf{w}})=\frac{1}{D_{\sf tot}}\sum_{({\mathbf{u}},v)\in\mathcal{D}}\sum_{c=1}^{C}{\bf 1}\{v=c\} log⁡exp⁡(𝐰c𝖳​𝐮)∑j=1Cexp⁡(𝐰j𝖳​𝐮)superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑐𝖳𝐮superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐶superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑗𝖳𝐮\displaystyle\log\frac{\exp({\mathbf{w}}_{c}^{\sf T}{\mathbf{u}})}{\sum_{j=1}^{C}\exp({\mathbf{w}}_{j}^{\sf T}{\mathbf{u}})}
+λ​∑c=1C‖𝐰c‖2,𝜆superscriptsubscript𝑐1𝐶superscriptnormsubscript𝐰𝑐2\displaystyle\qquad+\lambda\sum_{c=1}^{C}\|{\mathbf{w}}_{c}\|^{2},

where C=10𝐶10C=10 represents the total number of classes of handwritten digits; 𝐮𝐮{\mathbf{u}} is data image extended to include a bias term; and the model parameter 𝐰𝐰{\mathbf{w}}, with dimension 765076507650, is comprised of the per-class vectors {𝐰c}c=1Csuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐰𝑐𝑐1𝐶\{{\mathbf{w}}_{c}\}_{c=1}^{C}. We set λ=0.01𝜆0.01\lambda=0.01, the maximum value of ‖𝐰‖norm𝐰\|{\mathbf{w}}\| to W=10𝑊10W=10, the clipping threshold as γ^=40^𝛾40\widehat{\gamma}=40, and 𝖲𝖭𝖱𝗆𝖺𝗑=13subscript𝖲𝖭𝖱𝗆𝖺𝗑13\mathsf{SNR}_{\sf max}=13 dB. The smoothness parameter L𝐿L and strongly convex parameter μ𝜇\mu are treated as hyper-parameter and selected via validation as μ=0.3𝜇0.3\mu=0.3 and L=2.5𝐿2.5L=2.5. For ϵ=5italic-ϵ5\epsilon=5 and δ=0.01𝛿0.01\delta=0.01, Fig. 9 plots the training cross-entropy loss and the probability of error on the test set versus the value of communication budget I𝐼I for OMA. Adaptive PA is seen to significantly outperform static PA both in terms of training loss and test error. Similar results can be obtained for NOMA.

VI Conclusions

In this paper, we have considered differentially private wireless federated learning via the direct, uncoded, transmission of gradient from devices to edge server. The proposed approach is based on adaptive PA schemes that are optimized to minimize the learning optimality gap under privacy and power constraints. First, offline optimization problems are separately formulated for OMA and NOMA, which are converted to convex programs. The optimal PA, obtained in closed form, adapts the power along the iterations, outperforming static PA assumed in prior works. Furthermore, a heuristic online approach is proposed that leverages iterative one-step-ahead optimization based on the offline result and predicted CSI.

The analysis in this paper proved that privacy can be obtained “for free”, that is without affecting the learning performance, as long as the privacy constraint level is below a threshold that decreases with the SNR. Our analytical results also demonstrate that it is generally suboptimal to devote part of the transmitted power to actively add noise to the local updates. This is unlike the standard scenario with ideal communication, in which adding noise is essential to ensure DP constraints. Via numerical results, we have finally shown that techniques that leverage over-the-air computing provide significant benefits over conventional OMA protocols under DP constraints. This is not a prior evident, since, with NOMA, devices transmit more frequently, and hence may leak more information.

We note that the power control policy based on channel inversion for all the devices was proven to be suboptimal in the scenario of over-the-air computing without DP constraint. In fact, channel inversion can incur noise amplification by adapting the power to the device with worst channel condition [11, 38]. However, this may not be the case under DP constraints since noise amplification benefits privacy. As a possible extension of the current work, it would be interesting to study the optimization of the threshold for channel inversion so as to maximize the learning performance under privacy and power constraints. As directions for future work, the threat model could also include “honest-but-curious” edge devices, which would generally incur larger DP loss. The study could be further generalized to other network topologies including multi-hop device-to-device (D2D) networks. Another interesting direction is to consider the implementation of digital transmission where quantization introduces additional privacy preserving mechanism on top of the channel noise. It would also be interesting to investigate the effect of clipping in terms of convergence as in [44, 45], and to address the convergence properties of the proposed online scheme.

Then, the desired result in the theorem is obtained by reverting to the original variables using (56). Specifically, the optimal solution to minimize the transmit power is attained by the maximum value of (bk(t))𝗈𝗉𝗍subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘𝑡𝗈𝗉𝗍(b_{k}^{(t)})_{\sf opt} in (66).
